text:
oh my!!! this has got to be one of the yummiest things i've cooked lately!  i used organic DARK maple syrup.. natural soy sauce (tamrari) and made it in tin foil.. placed in a glass pie plate... opened during last 5 min or so and broiled it.. also drained off sauce.. reduced it in a small saucepan.. added a tiny bit of cornstarch, whisked it and poured over salmon on warmed dinner plates. Made carrots baked in the oven with a bit of butter and cinnamon and a cranberry wild/brown rice pilaf. :)  i'd say this is one my fav meals in a long time.. thank you soooo much.  i didnt use garlic salt.. i used 2 cloves of garlic and added a bit of ground sea salt... and freshly ground pepper. :):) sooo good.. will make for company for sure! :)

text:
The recipe was pretty good as is. I would specify that cooking salmon is not as simple as placing in oven for x amount of time. You should cook salmon based on thickness.
Bake uncovered in a preheated 450Â°F oven for 4-6 minutes for each .5 inch of thickness. As others have stated, you shouldn't marinade fish for any longer than 30 minutes. If you want the flavor to really soak in, marinade in tin foil to keep the marinade on the filet.
Great recipe idea and some great alternative ideas!!

text:
One of my favorites with this small variation. I bake in foil for 15 minutes and then break open the foil under the broiler for the last 4-5 minutes. This makes for a dryer crisper outer crust that our family likes.

text:
This is a great recipe with one change.  Add fresh ginger... I use about a tablespoon, or a little more/less to taste.  I also don't add garlic salt.  The soy sauce is enough to add plenty of salty taste and sodium.  To marinade this, I just place the glaze in a shallow dish and lay the salmon in it, skin up.  This works perfectly.  This is FABULOUS

text:
I have made this once.  My family REALLY liked it, especially me because it was easy.  The only thing I did different was instead of using a shallow baking dish I placed the salmon on foil,
poured on the sauce and wrapped it up so that there would be maximum sauce on salmon coverage.  I let it sit for 30 minutes as recommended and baked for about 25 to 30 minutes. No leftovers to store, no clean up and great fish...5 stars.  Good Luck!

************ Mondo- beyond extra stars!!!! This is the best way to do salmon- EVER!  In a restaurant or at home.  YUM!!!!!!!!!!!  I followed the recipe exactly- and added a tablespoon of horseradish.  (I knew it would be too sweet for us- we're spicy people here!)  This recipe is awesome and delish!  I cooked my salmon for 20 minutes and took the foil off for the last 5, spooned some of the sauce over the top after it came out and it was PHENOMENAL!!!!!!!  Rock my socks good!  Thanks so much for this recipe!  It is great!  UPDATE- made this again with thicker cuts of salmon and had to cook longer - maybe 40 mins.  The cooking time really seems to vary depending on the thickness of the fish.

text:
Even though my husband doesn't often enjoy "sweet" meat, he likes this one. I purchased frozen salmon and made up the marinade as the salmon was thawing. The changes I made: I don't like to use garlic salt so I decided to omit it. I used light maple syrup so I added a tablespoon of dark brown sugar (which oddly added a nice sweet hint of molasses). I minced up a two small cloves of garlic and added some extra garlic powder on top. I double layered a sheet of aluminum foil and set the mostly thawed pieces of salmon in with the mixture. I folded up the foil into a bag and set everything into a baking dish and turned the bag occationally while the salmon finished defrosting. While in the oven I flipped the bag over twice more and then at the end I opened the bag and broiled the top of the salmon for just about 3 minutes so the sugars could carmelize a little. *My filets were about 1 1/2 to 1 3/4 inches thick so I could beef up the flavor... maybe if yours are thinner you might add a little less, use your judgement.

text:
This was an interesting salmon recipe.  The maple syrup is very nice for the taste buds, though personally, I'd use a little less syrup.  (I used the real deal organic maple syrup, though, so perhaps the taste was a little stronger?)  Anyway, the problem I have with this recipe is the contrasting tastes.  Although syrup sounds fascinating when pairied with garlic and pepper and soy, the flavors seem at odds and even compete with each other. Especially the garlic.  It's just not a pleasant complement, aaccording to my family's preferences.  In fact, I'd say the whole recipe competes too much with the natural taste of salmon.  So, if you're a traditional fan, and love salmon + lemon/lime/etc, you might want to stick to that.  However, if you love sweets and don't mind heavy unusual- tasting dishes, this might be the recipe for you.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this twice. First following the recipe to the T and it was good, but I felt the flavor could be stronger.===  The second time I made it, I doubled the recipe and followed some suggestions posted in the reviews. I marinated it wrapped in tin foil to keep as much of the marinade on the fillet as possible. After 30 minutes, I placed the pouches on a baking sheet and baked them for 20 minutes at 400F.   While they were cooking I prepared another baking sheet with tinfoil and lightly greased it with cooking spray.   Removed salmon from oven. Very carefully I removed the fillets from the pouches and placed them on the second baking sheet, reserving the  liquid. Poured the liquid into a saucepan and added about 1/2 teaspoon of cornstarch.  Increased the oven temperature to Broil and returned the fillets to the oven for five minutes. Meanwhile, cooked the remaining liquid over medium-high heat for 2-3 minutes to thicken sauce. Served over fillets. DELICIOUS!!! My boyfriend and his brother both LOVED this recipe.

text:
I catch about 40-50 salmon a year so it is a staple food in the house. I made this recipe exactly as written, added a bit of cayenne because we like the heat. This is fantastic and simple! Most People overcook fish. I cooked for 13 mins at 360 and took the fillets out slightyly pink. By the time they are served they are PERFECT.. Remove fish from oven when slightly pink..Thanks for a great recipe!

text:
Very tasty without overpowering the taste of the salmon.  I had 1-1/2 lbs. of salmon and there was plenty of marinade.  I baked for 20 mins., then turned the oven off and let it bake for another 10 mins.  I did not have any problem with the marinade burning or drying up.  I brushed the sauce on the salmon a couple times during the baking process.  Great recipe, starflower!
**Note to melodysmall:  You have to use real maple syrup.  Mrs. Butterworth, and similar brands, are just corn syrup with flavoring.  The consistency isn't the same at all.  Once you start using real maple syrup, you won't want to go back.  Try a medium or light amber.

This is a decent base recipe but FRESH GRATED GINGER IS A MUST to make this recipe a real winner; before I added it the dish was unremarkable. Ginger root keeps very well in the freezer. Grate ginger over the top to your desired taste. YUM!

text:
Extraordinarily tasty--and beautiful to see!  I did this for guests and had rave reviews.  I followed several of the reviewer suggestions and it worked very well:

I used REAL maple syrup, added about 1/4 cup freshly squeezed orange juice, baked the salmon in a foil-lined pan for about 15 minutes, and then broiled it for 5 minutes.  It was tender and juicy with a gorgeous glazed look on top, and was very easy to clean up.

text:
I've made a recipe similar for years; it's a big hit esp. with my kids. I use FAR more garlic usually - I run 5-10 large cloves through the garlic press, until the glaze is almost a paste. Sometimes use a Tbsp. of fresh grated ginger as well. I've done this in the oven, under broiler, and on the grill with great results each time.

text:
Excellent marinade. What I like about this is that the sauce itself is not strong or overpowering in any way. It is a nice subtle sweet maple flavor and works real well with the salmon. The prep, ingredients, directions and baking time were all spot on! I did place the salmon in an aluminum foil, along with the marinade, 30 minutes prior to cooking. The salmon baked up, uncovered, at 400 degrees in 20 minutes. The salmon flaked easily with a fork. The marinade smelled very nice. The maple sauce was delicately sweet and I like the hint of soy sauce and garlic in the marinade. The salmon was tender, flavorful and melted in my mouth...Mmm. I am glad that this dish turned out real well. Mahalo STARFLOWER for sharing your recipe.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I don't like straying too far from plain grilled salmon with lemon & onion, but this was a great way to prepare salmon!  I had about 1.5 pounds of a beautiful piece of fresh wild king salmon filet which I placed in foil, added the marinade, sealed it up tightly so all of the salmon would be covered with the sauce, & refrigerated for 30 minutes.  Placed foiled salmon in baking dish and baked for probably 30+ minutes (it was a thick filet), opening foil up for half that time and basting the fish with the sauce.  For the marinade, I used low-salt soy sauce, added an extra garlic minced clove, and substituted garlic salt with garlic powder.  The maple syrup gave it a very nice but subtle sweetness.  Thank you, Starflower!

I took the suggestion of other reviewers and marinated and cooked the salmon in heavy-duty aluminum foil.  I would definitely make this for company; there is no better recipe for entertaining than one that is well received by guests with no major kitchen clean up. This recipe is a gem!

We are from the Pacific NW, so I have prepared salmon many different ways. As a matter of fact, I only use the standard lemon & dill, if I am going to be using it as an ingredient in a dish. That being said, this recipe gets 5 stars WAY up! :) I also followed the advice of another review that did not pour out the marinade, but instead added about a T (or so) of cornstarch, to create a very yummy sauce, while the fish was cooking in the oven. YUM & YUM, again!! :) Oh, and I did add approx 1 T brown sugar, but it would have still been 5 even without.

text:
This was wonderful. I doubled the glaze so that I would have more sauce (it's great drizzled over rice), and cut a pound of filets into six smaller pieces. I was able to fit three into a loaf pan, toast oven at 400 degrees for 20 minutes, and it was perfect. A pound of salmon makes for six servings if paired with some rice and a simple stir-fry. My friend declared that she loved salmon (she'd never had it before), and I, who loves seafood, found it to incredible - compliments withotu overwhelming the taste. I'm freezing the remaining three filets after marinating them for six hours. . . we'll see if that turns out well. :-D ... [It turned out amazingly well - the fish was fine and was now saturated with rich maple/soy sauce taste without being overwhelmed by it.]

This is simply the best way I've ever cooked/eaten salmon. A family member made maple salmon for dinner for me about 9 years ago, and I've always thought about it since. I decided to see if I could find my own recipe to try and recreate it, and I stumbled on this. It is AMAZING. userID:
1895117
Display Name:
Becky
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614242.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was great! It is now my regular way to make salmon. The original poster was right- do not let the salmon marinate for more than 30 minutes. Additionally, I was unsure if I should cook uncovered or covered- I wanted to try uncovered to see if the salmon would be more flakey rather than like it was steamed. I've now tried cooking it both covered and uncovered and found that covered is the way to go. The salmon and the glaze came out the same either way, but when it was uncovered, the glaze had burned to my dish that I was cooking it in, so I will cook it covered with aluminum foil when I cook this in the future. Additionally, I used low sodium soy sauce and a little garlic powder instead of garlic salt (I didn't have any)- I added a very little salt to make up for this and it still came out wonderfully. And definitely use pure/real maple syrup, rather than maple flavored syrup- it makes a difference.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was delicious and super easy to make.  I agree with other reviews, modify your cooking time depending on how think your salmon is.  Mine was fairly small & think, so i cooked for 15 minutes at 425 degrees, and it was perfectly done, yet moist.  I did marinate for the full 30 minutes too, as recommended, and I think this helps with good flavor

I didn't want the salmon to be too sweet, so I Halved the maple syrup.  It was PLENTY sweet, and I appreciate that we are eating less sugar.  I omitted the salt, and used low sodium soy sauce.  Again, this was a health choice, and it did not taste as if it needed more salt.  I added a little bit of fresh grated ginger (i highly recommend it, tastes quite nice).  Served this with home made fried rice (used brown rice and  steamed mixed veggies, friend it up with canola oil & onions).  Delicious & healthy meal, thank you for the recipe!

Excellent. I served it with whole wheat couscous and ratatouille.  As one reviewer suggested I added a tablespoon of minced ginger. You must use real maple syrup though. A few reviewers commented on the thickness of the marinade. If you're using real maple syrup! It isn't that thick. 
My only complaint is the burnt on marinade in my glass pan. I think next time I will marinate in one container and cook in another. Thanks for the excellent recipe STARFLOWER.

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/614318.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great way to prepare salmon, which is a good source of omegas and not too fatty.  I've made it a few times now and I've made a few observations: First, the recipe doesn't have to be exact at all, just get the proportions kinda close.  It's nice because you can just eye-ball this one.  Second, make sure your salmon is well covered in the marinade, it's so worth it.  Third, cooking time really does vary based on thickness when it comes to fish, don't be afraid to pop the oven open and check the flakiness.  Finally, don't marinade over 45 minutes... it changes the consistency of the meal for the worse.

This is a great marinade and it works for some tender cuts of pork really well too, just let it sit overnight.  I've had to give this recipe out to 6 people now, it's a hit with anyone, even non-fish-lovers.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Tasty recipe.  Use a good quality maple syrup as that is the dominate flavor in this dish.  We're salt sensitive, so I used half low sodium soy sauce and half regular and used a very large clove of garlic (and no garlic salt).  I marinated for about 2 hrs before baking and my fish was done in 18 minutes (should have pulled it a couple of minutes earlier).  Check early if you have thinner salmon.  Will have again.  Thanks for sharing.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674138.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is really good, but if you want the true sweetness of maple syrup to shine through, you'll need to go a bit further than the recipe takes you. I had planned to do what DESIDERATAGRACEFULLY did, reducing the marinade at the end, because I knew it wasn't going to be quite sweet enough for my taste. Unfortunately even though I packed it in foil, the juices ran out (I probably should've used more foil, lol) and they burned at the bottom of the pie plate. So when the salmon was done I tasted it and found I was right about the sweetness level so I drizzled a generous tablespoon of my favorite maple syrup over it to finish and for a hint of spice I oh so lightly dusted cayenne pepper over that, then it was perfect.   (TIP: My favorite real maple syrup is really thick, they use invert maple syrup to thicken it up, Shady Maple Farms organic thick and rich is the brand.)   I did also use the fresh garlic DESIDERATAGRACEFULLY recommended and some ginger because I love that flavor with maple. Anyway, I loved it when I was done, and I think it's my personal tastes for sweet and spicy that needed to revise the recipe, so I'm rating it a 5.

country:

text:
we have made this twice and both times have DOUBLED the marinade.This gave just the right of wonderful goo to spoon over after it had cooked and thickened a bit. I used a metal pan the first time and wouldn`t recommend that.It cooked hotter and thickened the souce too much,overcooking the sauce. A glass pan worked much better. I have greater success with salmon if it is slightly frozen in the middle when I start marinading it and even when starting to bake because salmon is best when not overcooked . Thanks,this was very tasty and we`ve done alot of salmon recipes. I also just left the maple syrup on the table and we drizzled extra on our fish after cooking.Goes beautifully with forbidden rice (a purple rice available in health food stores) steamed veggies and fresh cut pineapple!

Amazing. Wonderful.  Best salmon recipe ever. I'm not a huge salmon fan, but I LOVED this. I made this exactly as the recipe suggests except without the garlic salt. The soy sauce was enough salt. The sauce thickened up nicely as a glaze to pour over the salmon. I used this amount for 2 fillets, I would make a bit extra if I were making more portions. I can't wait to make this again!!!

This was delicious! I was not sure if I was supposed to leave the salmon in the marinade and bake, or not. I ended up pouring off the marinade into a saucepan. I cooked the salmon in foil for 15 minutes, then opened the foil packet and baked an additional 5 minutes. I cooked the sauce down and then drizzled it over the salmon when plated. text:
To play on the sweetness, I thought I would add in some ginger (a piece equal to the size of the garlic...and I used the garlic press to make sure it was crushed enough).  I also decided to not use garlic salt because I thought the soy sauce would be enough saltiness.  Instead, I used garlic powder.  So, here's what the family said:  My husband went on and on about how awesome it tasted; the kids thought it was a little sweet at first, but then liked it (so perhaps next time, I would keep the garlic salt instead of the garlic powder); personally, I thought it was fabulous!  The only reason I gave 4 stars is because I changed it up...to be fair, this was probably a 5-star to begin with.  However, do add that ginger.  You will enjoy the sweet and slightly spicy combo all the more.

I don't like salmon but when I saw that fresh salmon was on sale, I thought I would give it one more try. This recipe is amazing! I got 2 lbs of salmon in 2 fillets. I was so surprised that I liked it! Will definitely use again!

text:
really delicious, thanks for sharing.

my variations to the recipe:
- I didn't mince garlic, I just crushed a garlic clove and added to the marinate so it can be easily removed before cooking. 
- I added to the marinate some fresh ginger root (about 1 inch)  cutted in small stripes, I removed the ginger before serving.
- I didn't use garlic salt in the marinade but I sprinkled few salt flakes on the salmon just before serving.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very simple recipe that combines the classic taste of maple with the richness of salmon.  A true canadian classic.  One note regarding marinating times.  It is usually wise to marinate fish for 30 to 60 minutes max.  However, you can marinate longer, when you are not using an acid in the marinade, like lemon juice or vinagre.  This recipe can tolerate a longer marinade time, probably no more than 2 to 3 hours.  It will get more flavour, and the salmon is a hearty fish than can withstand the longer marinade time.  I would NOT do that with a more delicate filet.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I couldn't believe how good this was--or how easy it was to prepare.  At the last moment, I realized that I hadn't bought one of the crucial ingredients for the salmon burgers I'd intended to make, so I was left with a pound of salmon and a hungry husband.  I found this recipe and, after a quick pantry-check, decided to give it a try.  WOW!  I made a few minor changes, but the base-recipe is utterly solid.  I used maple-flavored agave syrup instead of maple syrup, 1/8 tsp. ground ginger in place of the black pepper, a little extra garlic, and I added a healthy dash of crushed red pepper flakes.  I marinaded it in the recommended glass baking dish, then baked it at the recommended time for 15 minutes.  I then gave it 5 more minutes in the broiler.  The fish was perfect--moist, flaky and flavorful.  I served it (and the remaining sauce!) atop buckwheat cooked in chickenbroth with peas and carrots.  We gobbled up every last bit.  Thank you for the wonderful recipe--it will have a permanent place on our rotation!

text:
I made this a while back for my husband. I bought a nice big fillet from Sams and got 4 good size servings. Used the ingredients listed except I gave it a splash of fresh lemon juice before I marinated the fish. I used a tsp of minced garlic from a jar since that was what I had on hand and I also added a tsp of grounded fresh ginger for a bit of heat instead of black pepper. I baked it baked it for 15 mins and than I removed it from the oven and drizzle the marinate over the fish with a tad more maple syrup and set it under the broiler for the last 5 minutes. Gave it a nice glaze! We ate it over a bed of rice. My husband loved it so much he went back for seconds and he scooped up some of the sauce to put it over his rice. He asked if I can make it again the next day!

Display Name:
margaux

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/766653.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I doubled the marinade--and used 2 filets. I always like to have more sauce! I also used about 4-6 garlic cloves (put thru a press), and omitted the garlic salt. I always use low sodium soy sauce, as well, and added about 1/4 cup olive oil to the marinade. I also reduced the marinade @ a low simmer by about a third or so, to have a sauce to pour over the fish. I put my salmon (wild) in a ziplock bag with the intention of marinating it 30 minutes. Unfortunately, my husband ended up having to work late, so it ended up marinating for about 1 1/2 hours, with no ill effects.   I cooked it as I always cook my wild salmon--bake, uncovered, at 275 for 20 minutes.  This is how I've been instructed to cook it by my salmon vendor/monger?--LOL! I'm on the Mexican border, so I order my fresh, wild salmon online. This turned out really good, but I would prefer to try it with some grade B maple syrup for a stronger maple flavor, as all I had available was grade A.  Good quantities of ingredients, just adjust according to your tastes!

This disappeared at my last family get together.  My husband dislikes salmon and said he would eat this anytime. I would have given 5 stars, but I modified the recipe just a bit. userID:
813104
Display Name:
OffRoadGal
isPro:

19

recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614254.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I wasn't sure about the sweet with the salmon. This was awesome, but I did it a little different.
I took the advice of marinading the salmon longer and I made extra marinade as well (tripled the recipe and used a third for the marinade).
I boiled the extra marinade down (stir it often!) till it was just getting thick (it got thicker as it cooled). 
After a couple hours of marinading the salmon, I threw the salmon, skin side down, on the grill and basted the top with the reduced marinade.
After about 8 minutes, the salmon was just starting to flake, I turned it over till it was just down.
While the salmon was finishing, I reheated the basting sauce, drizzled some over the salmon the plates and served the rest on the side.
My husband could not get enough of it!

Oh - and be sure to use REAL maple syrup!

text:
It's fantastic and it's SO easy! Anyone that likes salmon will love this recipe. I have also read that fish should not be marinated more than 1/2 hour, but I generally marinade the salmon longer. The reason stated for less marinating time is the fish tends to get mushy. I've never had this problem with the salmon. It holds up extremely well and is always perfectly flaked. Personally, I wouldn't be too concerned about the marinade time on this one.

text:
If you don't want a sticky mess, what I normally do is just put salt, pepper and olive oil on the salmon prior to baking, and I make a reduction out of the other ingredients on the stovetop.  I use maple syrup, soy, balsamic vinegar, garlic, sugar and some chili flakes, and reduce for about 15 mins (until syrupy).  Then pour it on top of the salmon.

userID:

Display Name:
Anne Westeen Greasley
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7437588.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is one of the best recipes I've found on this website!  I increase the garlic to 5 or 6 cloves and omit the pepper.  I usually cook this on my grill, so I double the sauce and marinate the salmon in half of the sauce in a ziploc for an hour.  I wrap the salmon in heavy duty foil and cook it on the upper rack of my grill for 1/2 hour.  Warm the reserve sauce and pour it over the salmon before serving.  This winter, I did cook it in foil in a glass baking dish in the oven when it was too cold to use my grill.  I found it was not necessary to double the sauce when cooked this way.  I have served this for family dinners and for dinner parties and received rave reviews every time!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used one pound of salmon for two people, however I cut the rest of the ingredients in half to cut down on sugar and salt.  I also omitted the garlic salt and black pepper but used 1/2 clove of fresh garlic.  After baking for 20 minutes, I checked for doneness and determined it needed a little longer.  However the sugar from the maple syrup was burning in the dish, so I transferred the salmon and wrapped it in aluminum foil to finish baking for about another 5 minutes. I thought the salmon was quite tasty; my husband would have liked a little more maple taste but doesn't really want that much sugar.  I would make it again using the same ratio of ingredients but next time I will bake it in either parchment paper of aluminum foil right from the start.

This was the very first time I ever made salmon and it was delicious!!!  My family loved it!  I used garlic powder instead of the garlic salt because I was afraid it would be too salty!  I also put tin foil over the cooking dish until the last 5 minutes!  Turned out better than perfect!  I made a 2nd batch of the glaze in a bowl, put it in the microwave until it bubbled, stirred then poured it over the salmon after it was finished! Definitely needed it!  Served with sweet potatoes and a side salad!  Will be a weekly dinner at my house!  Thanks for sharing this recipe!

text:
We're attempting to find ways to cook fish that my husband will like.  This recipe certainly fit the bill, he loved it.  I made two changes; I left out the minced garlic as I was concerned about too much garlic overwhelming the salmon's flavor and also substituted garlic powder for garlic salt as soy sauce is very high in sodium.  I cooked it in a foil packet for 30 minutes then opened the packet and cooked it for 15 more minutes.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674159.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Absolutely delicious!  I marinated the salmon, skin up, in a heavy duty foil packet for about 1 hour. I left out the garlic salt because I didn't have any.  I minced up some fresh garlic, and just used a tiny bit of salt, low sodium soy sauce, pure maple syrup, and ground black pepper. I baked it inside the packet placed inside a glass dish, for about 15 minutes, then opened the foil and broiled it for about 5 minutes.  I didn't add any thickening agents to the sauce, just spooned it as it was over the fish and the rice I served with it.  I loved it - my daughter said "Yuck, salmon is too fishy tasting for me" so I ate her portion too!! There is one small piece left, so tomorrow I'll have it for lunch on a bed of mixed greens - I can't wait!! I will definitely be making this again!! Thank you STARFLOWER for this scrumptious fish dish!!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2169404.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I must start off by saying that I don't care too much for fish, so I'm always on the look out for a fabulous recipe that will change me from a "meh-fish-liker" to a "total fish lover". This recipe did it for me!

I followed the recipe to a T, using real maple syrup. After baking the fish, I poured the sauce residue into a saucepan, added a pinch of flour, and reduced it on high heat to create a glaze. 

I served my fish with white rice. I tasted it without the glaze first and found that the thinner parts of the fillet harboured a delicious flavour. The thicker areas retained the marinade flavour, just not as strong. I poured the glaze over the thicker parts of the fillet, just to adjunct the taste. 

Verdict: This recipe yielded the best fish recipe I have ever eaten. It will be a staple in my house.

text:
We truly loved it.  Yes- you have to enjoy fish with a sweet flavor, and YES- you have to use REAL maple syrup.  Forget the fake stuff for this recipe - it will change everything.  Also- use low sodium soy sauce-its less overbearing! I also added fresh onion, and I put a little butter on top of the salmon filets as they were cooking, I think that helps with the texture issue some were complaining about.  Served it with Indian style basmati rice, sauteed spinach, and scallion pancakes!  We both loved it and will try again with a little ginger!  Also, I used frozen salmon-I think fresh is the way to go for this one! Kudos!

text:
I made this salmon recipe tonight, almost exactly as stated. Used the same ingredients and measurements. I did NOT let it marinate because I found it last minute so didnt have time, but it didnt matter. It was delicious! Definitely will be making again.

*Hint for baking salmon: Place pan of salmon in a cold oven. Turn oven on to 425 and bake 25 mins. Makes perfect salmon every time, no need to wait for oven to preheat. :)

text:
Awesome, but also followed the recommendation of another reviewer and poured the marinade off into a small sauce pan, added corn starch, and poured it over the salmon at the end. My filets were fairly thin, maybe 1.25" thick, so I only cooked my salmon for 12 min. at 400 and then broiled for 3 min. Very flaky and still very moist.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have been making this recipe for 2 years now.  It is the only recipe I use for salmon.  Can't get past it to try anything else.  I make the recipe as is with no changes until it comes out of the oven.  I remove the salmon from the baking dish and place on a serving dish.  I transfer the remaining sauce to a small sauce pan and thicken with a little cornstarch & water stirring over medium heat.  I then spoon the thickened mixture over the salmon pieces.  Everyone I've ever cooked this recipe for loves it!

text:
I read the reviews and decided to omit the garlic salt in favor of two more fresh cloves of garlic.  I would have loved to have added fresh ginger, but I didn't have any on hand, so I added some ground ginger as well as some chipotle powder for some extra kick - about an 1/8 tsp.  I baked it foil for about 10 min, then uncovered it for the last 5 min.  I used a bag of salmon fillets and served this with green tea jasmine rice and green beans.  Absolutely delicious!!

text:
I love this recipe - so easy and great flavor!  The only change I make is to exchange garlic powder for the garlic salt (I don't like things too salty, so the soy sauce is plenty of salt for me).  My fiance doesn't like fish normally, but he loved this recipe and asked to have it again the next week.  It's worth it to get good (real) maple syrup, but I tried it with Hungry Jack syrup once when we were out of the real stuff, and it still had a great taste.  I like to serve it with a brown rice/wild rice blend and steamed carrots.

text:
Wow!  I am not a fish lover but this recipe has changed my mind.  It was amazing!  Great flavors!  I followed the advice of another reveiwer and baked in foil for 15 minutes (to avoid burning the garlic), then opened it up under the broiler for the last 5 minutes, basting with the sauce often.  Other than that I followed the recipe exactly.  The salmon was so moist and delicious.  I am going to add this to my dinner rotation for sure!  Thanks Starflower!!

text:
I followed this recipe exactly (except using low sodium soy sauce, but I'd hardly count that as an alteration) and it turned out wonderful!  Perfect balance of salty and sweet, perfect texture of the sauce (marinade) without having to add anything to it.  I cooked the salmon a little longer than 20 mins, just because I had some thick filets, but the flaking method is really my preferred test for fish.  I'd recommend this recipe to anyone wanting to bake a savory, unique salmon dish.

Display Name:
lilyorchid

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614246.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The marinade is good.  It doesn't completely penetrate the fish just from marinating for 30 minutes, so if you want to mask the taste of the fish, I'd suggest setting aside some of it before marinating the raw fish in the rest, bake your fish (12 minutes at 190 C worked for my smaller piece), then cut up the fish into pieces and pour the marinade that you set aside (that did not touch raw fish) over the cooked fish pieces.   That will help hide the salmon flavor, if that's your goal.  I am new to cooking salmon, but this sauce is good, I don't find it too sweet at all, used real maple syrup and soy sauce, a large garlic clove, and just plain salt and pepper.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/705502.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Five stars due to the uniqueness of flavoring salmon this way.  This is a solid, uncommon dish.   Nice variation from lemon juice and dill...

The sauce can also be used as a good dipping sauce for grilled chicken.  We cooked out at work today for lunch, and both the grilled salmon and grilled chicken went with the maple sauce very well.

I put the marinade/sauce in an 8x8 aluminum foil pan, put salmon in, placed (covered) in fridge for 30 min.  Took out, wrapped in aluminum foil (poured a little marinade on bottom of foil before sealing), threw on a med/med-high grill for 15 minutes.  Came off the grill light-pink and perfect.  Made a second batch of the maple sauce for dipping.  Zer gut!

I made this as per the directions with one tweak.  However just a minute or two before it was ready to come out of the oven I sprinkled brown sugar on the salmon and put the oven on broil. Watch it carefully so it won't burn and then pull out when the sugar is bubbling. It was perfect. I also glazed the salmon with the sauce 3 times throughout the cooking process.

None
text:
Excellent recipe - very tasty!  I just have two recommendations:  1) Add 1/2 teaspoon of brown sugar to the marinade - I like a little bit of extra sweetness; 2)  Cook each fillet in a little foil packet.  Wrap each one in aluminum foil (leaving some space for the air to circulate inside) and cook at 425 F for about 15 minutes.  Doing this makes the fish super moist and very flavorful!  Overall, great recipe!  It tastes great and it unbelievably easy to make!

text:
W...O...W.  This recipe was fantastic.  I was a little skeptical at first because I didn't want anything too sweet, but I wanted something different than the other 2-3 salmon recipes I make all the time.  I followed CourtneyGriff's suggestion and added horseradish! Here were my modifications: 1) 2 cloves garlic instead of 1  2) Omitted the garlic salt 3) Added 1 heaping TSP. of horseradish (was afraid of adding the recommended 1 TBSP, but I think the amount we added cut the sweetness perfectly) 4) Wrapped in foil for about 25 minutes, then broiled on low for 3 minutes.  Probably could have broiled longer - it didn't get crispy on the outside.  This was the moistest salmon with just the right touch of flavor.  Perfect enhancement.  Thanks for the recipe, Starflower.  We will make this often!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4584574.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is absolutely delicious! After making this several times, I've decided that doubling the marinade is the way to go. You can easily reduce it on the stove-top until it reaches the consistency of a glaze, or thicken it with cornstarch to create the consistency of a sauce. We always omit the garlic salt, as soy sauce tends to be salty enough on its own. I think the addition of ginger truly adds to this dish, whether you use dried or fresh minced. Add it to taste. Also, if you don't have maple syrup, table syrup makes a great substitute though it may taste a little sweeter. You can do this on the stove-top as well, but I find it less flaky and juicy as opposed to baking the salmon in the oven. Great with rice and steamed vegetables.

text:
Why Allrecipes never put this in their cookbook is beyond me. Clearly a fan-favorite, this dish is easy, healthy, and a crowd-pleaser for anyone who even remotely likes fish. 

With only 6 common ingredients, this is and my absolute favorite recipe (and easiest), I've already hand-written this recipe down and put in cookbooks of recipes I give as gifts (don't worry, I add the URL at the bottom to give the original inventor credit)! This recipe also works well just to marinade and grill the salmon over charcoal- wood chips, especially cedar, make this a recipe to rival any frou-frou restaurant (and gas grills just ruin the true flavor of almost anything)!

The flavor is just right, not overdone sweetness, but a great combination of flavors.  I used jarred garlic with ginger, since I was out of plain garlic, and it was delicious.

text:
Wow!  This recipe is truly great for the colder months!  I only made one minor change, and that was to omit the garlic salt and instead use two cloves of fresh garlic.  I may try adding some fresh ginger in the future as other users have mentioned, but it turned out to be a wonderful dish last night "as is".  I served it over some brown basmati rice and topped it with the remaining sauce, along with a side of roasted broccoli made simply with fresh garlic, olive oil and a hint of red curry paste.  My husband even gave me the "so are you going to have seconds?" look and dove in to finish off what was left in the dish!  I will be adding this to my recipe book with pride!

city:

country:
None
text:
I followed the recipe except I used 1/4 cup maple syrup to 1/4 cup soy sauce and doubled the recipe. 1/2 went onto the fish in the marinade.  I added another quarter cup of maple syrup to the remaining 1/2 of the original mix, heated to boiling, then simmered on low  for about 10 min. Added 1/4 cup chopped pecans 1/2 way through. Removed from heat and then mixed in 2 or 3 tablespoons cream (I can't remember how many tablespoons, but cream makes it taste a little bit like maple caramel-just add to taste.)   Delicious!

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674168.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed the advice of my chef friend, and you all should too!  Don't bake it!  Cook in a skillet for 5-10 minutes with a buttered sheet of parchment paper on top of the salmon.  It comes out very moist this way, and it cooks all the way through in a very short amount of time.  Also, don't worry if your salmon doesn't cook all the way through.  It's not like chicken; it's ok to eat some of it uncooked!  I also used real maple syrup, I think that was key to the flavor.  I normally don't like salmon, but this was awesome!  I'll definitely be making it regularly.

text:
My family enjoys sweet flavors so this was hit. I noticed comments stating the fish could have marinated longer however keep in mind fish is not poultry or red meat. Trying to marinate longer than 1 hour won't intensify the flavor nor will the flavors reach the interior, so save your time.

text:
Hold on to your hats, this one is a KEEPER!  My reluctant husband kicked his legs in delight after tasting this salmon!  The flavor is delicate, delicious, and I didn't have to jazz up the recipe at all.  I cannot understand why some people rated this one low, did they use the wrong kind of syrup or something (I used Grade A dark amber)? I'd have to say this is perhaps the easiest and best salmon recipe I've ever made! I did marinate mine in a ziplock bag and next time I think I'll make extra sauce to serve along with the salmon - I was scraping up the sauce from the corners of the pan.  Fabulous all around!

text:
This was INCREDIBLY DELICIOUS and EASY!!  I can't say enough for this recipe!  I followed the recipe exactly (used real maple syrup) except that I finely crushed up walnuts (pecans would have been good, too) and put on top of salmon right before baking, then carefully spooned the marinade on top of the walnuts.  I baked for 10 minutes, then spooned the marinade again on the salmon and baked for the remaining 10 minutes; 20 minutes was the perfect cooking time.  I've had a dish that tasted exactly like this in one of my favorite restaurants, so I will surely be making this often!

text:
Good recipe, but I was expecting more based on the reviews.  I marinated my salmon for exactly 30 minutes, but if I were to do it again, I would marinate longer.  I just didn't taste the maple/soy/garlic taste after cooking. (perhaps running it under the broiler for a few minutes after cooking would bring out some of the flavor?)  And I would highly recommend you line your pan with foil - - cooked maple syrup can really be a mess to clean up!

text:
This was super and my family of 5 all enjoyed it. I used  5 oz pieces of fish per person which was perfect. It's not easy to find something my teenagers all like. But I took the fish out of the bag of sauce after 30 minutes and placed it in the pan, skin side down. I then put the sauce in a small pan and added some corn starch. It boiled for a while. I drizzled it over the fish. This is absolutely what made the difference for the kids and why they liked it so much. I will make this again.
I made it again  Jan 2019 and my boys and fiance liked it even more.  We doubled the recipe with a 2.5 pound salmon.  I had tons of sauce to boil with corn starch. But the sauce, again, made the difference to the kids.

text:
The marinade is wonderful! Thanks to the other reviewers for their ideas, which I promptly stole. :) Doubled the marinade ingredients and used low sodium soy. Marinated the salmon filets and then cooked them wrapped in foil (still in the marinade). Halfway through, I moved the marinade to a sauce pan, thickened with cornstarch, and served atop the filets. My teenager cleaned his plate and I wanted to lick the serving spoon. The marinade/sauce would be amazing on many things, not just salmon. Thanks to Starflower for the easy and delicious recipe!

ABSOLUTELY DELICIOUS!! So quick, no fuss and so tasty! I followed the recipe exactly. I marinated 2 pieces of salmon flesh side down and started baking it flesh side down for 10 minutes and then flipped it over, skin side down to complete the cooking. 20 minutes ended up being perfect for the nice thick piece of salmon I purchased. HIGHLY RECOMMEND this recipe!!

text:
Excellent!  I tweaked it a bit as I'm a health nut.  No aluminum - toxic.  Used a cookie sheet to marinade and bake in with a handful of snow peas in the sauce too. Did 2 cloves garlic instead of garlic salt and used maple syrup from a friend's sugar bush in Ontario which I know is pure - awesome dinner.  Thanks for posting.

text:
This dish is perfect because it is both easy and delicious and now it's the only way I fix salmon. The first time I made it I didn't have soy sauce, just teriyaki sauce. I decided to go ahead and it was just great so that's how I've continued to make it. It's good with any maple syrup, but the one time I made it with the really good (expensive!) stuff, it took it to a whole new level. I triple the recipe and use a 3 lb slab of salmon from our local warehouse store. That way there are leftovers and it reheats very nicely (I keep all of the sauce).

text:
This recipe is great, easy, and a crowd pleaser. I would recommend adding 1/4 cup of brown sugar to the marinade. Also, there is more than just "flaking the fish" to check and see if it is fully cooked. Be sure to use a food thermometer in the thickest spot of the fish and assure that it cooks to 145 degrees. Don't need food poisoning!

Amazing!  I'm pretty new to even eating fish & I've never made it at home before today.  Took couple of recommendations. 1. cut out garlic salt and did extra fresh garlic (there's plenty of salt in soy sauce) 2. Marinated then baked in foil to lock in flavors 3. Opened foil the last 5 min & broiled to get crispy.  Will totally make again!

Debbie

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674167.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Saw this on the "daily" recipes and thought it sounded interesting.  I had just defrosted a large salmon filet and hadn't decided what to do with it yet. We are presently vacationing in a rather remote location and this recipe with its 5 basic marinade ingredients fit the bill nicely. Prepared according to directions & added a sprinkle of red pepper on top of the salmon just before I cooked it in the convection toaster oven. It turned out great! I lined the pan with foil & non-stick spray before inserting salmon pieces & marinade. Went from frige, to oven & cooked uncovered at 400 for about 30-40 min. Salmon was moist with slightly crusty top & the marinade had thickened by itself to a nice sauce. Because of cooking spray, nothing stuck to the foil. Hubby loved it too. Afterwards, he just rolled up the foil & clean-up was done! Thanks for the recipe; this is a keeper.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wonderful recipe.  I've made it several times.  It's easy to prepare and always comes out absolutely delicious.  It's better than what you would get in most restaurants.  

A couple notes: 1) Be sure you are using a glass dish.  If you don't have one on hand, you can use a metal baking pan, but know that the maple sauce will start to burn on the pan so you need to keep an eye on it closely and be prepared to scrape your metal pan clean.  The fish will still be delicious, though.  2) This recipe sometimes takes longer than 20 minutes to cook fully.  Even if the fish is flaking, check the center to make sure it no longer has a somewhat jelly appearance.

Really great recipe.

text:
Starflower, just to let you know I added this to my recipe file back in April 2010 and since then to date, I've made it many times.  My family loved it just the way you wrote it so I don't bother to change it when it works!  I marinated it for 15 minutes on both sides and baked it til it flaked easily with a fork.  That depends on the thickness of the salmon, too.  I try to select the salmon in pieces that are all relatively close in size. No guesswork for me and no worries about one thinner piece being more done than the rest.  Again, we loved it.  I apologize for not having written a review until now. Great flavor. Thank you for sharing an out of the ordinary delicious fish recipe!

I wouldn't cook it any other way!

country:
None
text:
Absolutely amazing! Will definitely be a staple in our home! I have to add that there is a trick to this recipe with respect to the marinade.  If you found it too bland, it is important to keep "basting" the marinade over the salmon. So, 1) during the half way point while still in the fridge 2) prior to baking 3) shortly before being done and 4) when served. I added an extra 5 mins to baking time, but people forget that location (aka altitude) may vary cooking time.

text:
I reviewed this recipe in 2012 and it is still my favorite salmon recipe!!  Actually, I buy my salmon at Costco because it is very fresh and I never have to worry about it being bad.  I use the aluminum pan that the salmon comes in. I take the dill off of the Costco salmon.  I go by the recipe except I add fresh ginger or ginger in a tube and I now cook in the oven for 20 minutes and then take it to the grill for another five minutes- just long enough to make it crispy. I really want to thank Starflower for this recipe -outstanding! I have used it for several years and it is absolutely the very best!! It is my go to recipe when we have dinner guest - always compliments.

text:
Ohhh my gosh, so good. I have made this for a few people and they all loved it! It's so easy but tastes gourmet. :D I make it exactly as-is, except instead of garlic salt I use garlic powder to cut the sodium. I also make a little extra marinade to put on TOP about 5 minutes or so before fully cooked... also to flavour rice if that's our side dish. :) Another option is to add a bit of cornstarch to the extra marinade, heat a little to thicken, let cool and drizzle on top of the cooked salmon - I think that would make it particularly kid/picky eater friendly! ;)

Absolutely delicious.  I made a few changes.  After marinating in fridge for 30 minutes, I baked for 15 minutes than took it out of the oven and sprinkled some garlic poweder, onion powder, paprika, sazon, salt, black pepper, and put a little bit of butter on it and then placed it back in the oven on broil for the last 5 minutes as suggested by another reviewer.  It was finger licking good.  My husband loved it!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I threw my own version of some splash cookin to get those hot and sweet flavors, I love, by adding a half cup local brew beer( Northwest thing ), a dash of spicy mustard, four shakes of your favorite hot sauce, and along with the staples of the delicious recipe of Maple Syrup and Soy, and of course garlic, I added fresh local honey, and in exchange for salt and pepper used Uncle Lou's Hot and Spicy, and Herb and Garlic for seasoning. I baked low for 15 minutes(used fresh salmon from Costco), then brolied for 15 at 500, marinating every five minutes. It came out moist in the middle and so yummily coated on top. I used a glass cooker with foil for the low part, and took off foil for the briol. Had no idea what I was doing, except I had salmon, syrup, garlic, and soy sauce. LOL

text:
The sweetness of the maple requiers more seasoning in my opinion, ginger, wasabi and sesame oil would be a good addition, I also don't like salmon when it flakes, it is overcooked by then for my taste and dry. I prefer it when it's nicely browned on top but very pink inside and doesn't flake, it is more creamy and tastes better in my opinion, I would broil it few minutes on each side but not close to the broler, not to burn the fish, just brown it well.

Made this for a dinner party & it was a hit! Everyone, including my boyfriend who doesn't like fish, ate his whole piece of salmon! It turned out absolutely wonderful! I don't think I'd make this again based on the cleanup alone.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I guess I had high expectations with this recipe because I am not as satisfied as I thought I would be.  To get the full sweet taste, I kept having to scoop a lot of glaze with every bite of salmon.  Probably because I should have marinated the salmon for the instructed time of 30 minutes. (I took it to bake after 20 minutes. Couldn't wait!)  Another change I would make the next time I cook this is adding cornstarch to thicken the glaze, as recommended by DESIDERATAGRACEFULLY, and adding ginger. And like most reviewers stated, wrap in foil and open up at last 5 minutes.  Hope it'll taste better next time.  Overall, great taste! 4 stars.

text:
And I'm trying to see what else the recipe needs to help balance out the soy/syrup flavor. It's great, but it can always be greater. I tried 1/8 t of marjoram, and 1/8 of onion powder. It didn't really make a difference (although that's when I didn't marinate)

Tried it for the fourth time, but since I needed to make the salmon before it went bad and to make a movie in an hour, I didn't marinate it at all. In one bite it was blatantly obvious it wasn't the same recipe. Without the marinating process, it tastes dry like a turkey and other like other fish. Marinating simply ISN'T OPTIONAL.

I love the sweetness of the sauce. It probably only needs 18 minutes in the oven.   Love how easy to make and delicious it is!

text:
I am not a huge fan of salmon, but I made this last night for my son, who loves salmon.  It was delish!!  It was the perfect balance of sweet/savory.  I used frozen salmon fillets, as I wasn't sure about whether or not we would even like it, so I didn't want to go crazy on the fresh stuff.  Take the other reviewers suggestion and mince your galic REALLY well because baking time doesn't really allow it to soften much.  This was a super quick and easy dinner, and even I (not a salmon lover) would recommend it to everyone!  We are making it again tonight!

text:
This was a great way to do salmon. My changes; omit garlic salt, use 2 cloves and about 1/2 tsp. sea salt. increase to 1/4 tsp. ground black pepper and a dash of red pepper. Baked it covered for 15 mins. uncovered and broiled for the last 4 or 5 mins. Added about 2 tbsp. of Amaretto Disaronno to small pan on med high heat for a couple of mins. and added the leftover marinade and reduced it for another 2 or 3 mins. Wow this was good.

text:
I've been making this recipe for years, and it always gets two thumbs up! I change up the recipe a little (minced onion instead of minced garlic, double the measurement; garlic powder instead of garlic salt, reduced to half the measurement), and grill instead of bake. I wrap the salmon in tin foil and place on the lowest rack of the barbeque for about 20 minutes. It always turns out perfect!

text:
This was very good.  I never made salmon in my life and it turned out great.  I didn't know the salmon fillets you purchased still had the skin on it.  It took me awhile to remove the skin because I didn't have a very sharp knife.  I ended up pulling the skin and scales off with ease.   One thing I would say about this recipe is that the cooking time seems very long.  I cooked it for 30 mins and it was just a tad dry- I think 25 mins would  have been better.  I guess it depends on your oven so keep checking so it doesn't dry out.  I served with brown rice and mixed veggies this was very very good and not fishy at all to my surprise!  After eating this salmon I thought wow.. why do people eat chicken when fish tastes this good!

text:
You can't go wrong with this! I added scallions and made a touch extra on the side to brush on a few minutes before it was done. I grilled this on a soaked cedar plank so I marinated 30 minutes, set it on a grid over foil for about 15 minutes to let it "glaze", then put it on the plank and grilled. Oh, man, even our 18 year old picky eater commented again this morning how good it was! This is a keeper! It won't disappoint no matter how you cook it! I will be making this many times this summer! Thank you!!

userID:
1706815
Display Name:
Dawn
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674134.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I (we) made this for a cooking class I had at my house one evening.  EVERYONE, even those who said they didn't like salmon beforehand, LOVED this dish! (Even one very picky husband!)  To make this completely mess-free, we put all the marinade ingredients in a large zip-lock bag, zipped it up, smushed all the ingredients together to mix them, and then placed the salmon inside to marinate for 30 minutes.  We then made foil pockets, placed a filet in each one, dumped the marinade over the top, sealed them up, and baked as directed.  The only clean up we had were the plates we ate off!  Oh, one other thing, I had several people who couldn't have sugar, so we made some with sugar-free maple syrup and we couldn't tell the difference!  It was delicious both ways!
Enjoy!

text:
This recipe was delicious! I substituted soy sauce for Worcestershire sauce, as it tends to have less sodium than even the low-sodium soy sauce. It was very simple also. A way to have the salmon marinade quicker is to put it into the freezer instead of the fridge. The salmon will absorb more of the flavor in the same amount of time. The salmon was also perfectly pink and tender, neither dried nor undercooked. My son even liked its sweet flavor!

text:
Everyone loved this, even those who do not share my love of salmon.  I never delete ingredients from well-reviewed recipes, but I can't help it when other reviews add to the recipe with ingredients that I adore.  So, I doubled the sauce because I had 2 lbs of salmon- (could have easily handled 2 1/2 lbs) Added 2 T fresh minced ginger and 1/2 T horseradish.  Marinated 30 minutes skin side up.  Flipped it to bake.  Did not have any problem with sauce burning.  Spooned sauce over a few times while baking.  Garnished with chopped scallions.  Just wish I made more, so I could have some cold for lunch!  Fantastic- our new favorite for "oven" salmon.  Still love firecracker salmon, on this site, for grilling!

text:
We live in salmon country, and I've cooked it many ways . . .this is by far the one recipe my family requests over and over.  Regardless of what others have said, I think a longer marinade (more like an hour if the salmon is thicker) in the fridge enhances the garlic flavor in the recipe.  And as others have pointed out--every piece of salmon should be checked thoroughly--maybe less than 20 minutes, maybe more.  Thanks for the recipe--it's a keeper!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I am on a low-carb/low-sugar diet.  I used sugar-free syrup (Mrs. Butterworth's).  This was delicious, healthy, and extremely easy to make.  I marinated fish in TRIPLE the amount of marinade, in a ziplock (pressed all the air out), in the fridge.  I lined an 8x8 square baking pan with foil (for easy clean-up).  I poured the fish and ALL the marinade in the pan.  The fish cooked in the marinade, leaving lots to spoon on top of the fish when I served it.  It was AWESOME!  This will be a regular for me!  Thank you for this time-saving, delicious idea!!

text:
I made this for the second time last night and it was a HUGE hit!  I was told...this recipe is a keeper, I donât need some for lunch, Iâm eating it all now!  I marinated it longer than 30 minutes, overnight actually (I've done this before with seafood without any adverse reactions) turning it over in the morning before work.  I added crushed red peppers, cayenne pepper and Â¼ tsp of chili oil  for some heat.  The first time I made this, I added onion, shallots and green onions.  Yesterday, just before baking the salmon,  I sliced an onion,  making sure to let them sit in the marinade not just on the fish so they weren't dry; everything was so oooh oooh good.

text:
This is naturally a sweet recipe, and kids and husbands enjoy it. I would serve it with something simple and savory as it so sweet: an herb risotto, couscous with pine nuts, etc. I did not add garlic salt and I wouldn't recommend it. Soy sauce is extremely salty on its own, and the recipe already calls for fresh garlic. More salt plus fake garlic seems pointless. All said, this is fast,easy,and crowd-pleasing.

text:
Very tasty. The first time I made this, I forgot to bake it and fried it in the marinate instead. The second time I baked as instructed. I actually like it fried better! The sugar in the syrup carmelized, adding an intriguing texture to the meat, as well as better preserving the flavor of the marinade. Baking is definitely a safer way to go though, and it came out perfectly moist and ready to serve!

city:

country:
None
text:
We especially love this recipe cooked on the grill (on aluminum foil).  10 minutes top side down, then flip to skin side down, and brush with more marinade for 10 more minutes.  I also double the marinade, keeping half aside, so it can be used to flavor steamed carrots as a side dish.  Steam sliced carrots till tender, drain water, and saute carrots in leftover marinade. Oven roasted new potatoes round out the meal.  The garlic salt is not necessary, and make sure you use real maple syrup.  Just wonderful!

Salmon turns out absolutely amazing, just make sure you use 100% pure maple syrup, it makes a big difference.  I also added a tbsp. of freshly grated ginger and it was really good.  I marinated the salmon overnight in a foil lined pan and then just popped it in the oven when the time came.  I allowed 1/2 hour and it came out perfect.  My sauce didn't burn off at all so I was very happy about that.    Thanks for posting.

text:
This was wonderful. As other have said, it is a very subtle maple flavour that comes through the salmon and the result is a light but flavorful dish. I have made this many times exactly as written and it is wonderful every time. DO NOT marinate longer than 30 minutes as salmon takes on a bitter flavour if you do. 

2008- I have to now add that this recipe so impressed a guest (set-up date) that he asked me out again and a year later, we got married. I expect it took more than a great recipe (!) but my now husband still asks for the dish that "reeled him in"!!

text:
I (along with most of my family) was skeptical of this one. I must say we were all proven wrong! I made this almost as written - I had no garlic salt so used almost 2 cloves garlic and a small pinch of salt instead. Then reduced the marinade down and thickened with a bit of corn starch and drizzled a bit over top when serving.  Was a HUGE hit. Have made with Atlantic Salmon and Coho. Coho won hands down. Definately worth a try... Thanks!

I carmelized the sauce by adding corn starch and whisking on the stove top to drizzle over the fish.  I topped with coarsely chopped pecans during the last 10 mins. of baking.  I served with brown rice and veggies.  The flavor of the extra sauce and the nuts were perfect!  A new favorite.  Thanks!

text:
Wow ... this was probably the best salmon I've ever had. I don't eat much fish and I almost never cook it at home because I hate the fishy smell in the house. But this really smells wonderful while it cooks! Some people say that 20 minutes doesn't seem like enough cooking time, but personally, I thought it was perfect since I don't like fish overcooked. Also, I marinated the salmon for 2 1/2 hours to give it more depth of flavor, lined the baking dish with foil and cooked the fish in the marinade, and basted it twice with the marinade during cooking. Absolutely delicious and my husband wants it on the "regular rotation"! Thanks, Starflower!  :o)

text:
Yum!!! So easy & so good. Wild Salmon is on sale right now!!! I think those of you who had sticking problems must have used pancake syrup. Use real maple syrup- much tastier & not as thick as, say, Log Cabin! It is more expensive, but worth it! It would probably be even better if you broil it a few minutes after cooking, but I'm lazy & it tastes great as written. It won't be too salty if you use low-sodium soy sauce. I bake mine for 25-30 minutes. I'm pleasantly surprised that the # of carbs isn't too bad! I figured it would be with the maple syrup. Thanks for submitting!!!

I'm doing at least 30 minutes each time.  That said...turning it over once while baking is also really a great way to do this dish.  Serve w/ steamed asparagus and it is a great meal!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I saw this recipe on the website while I was at work.  Since I already had the salmon and all the ingredients for this recipe I decided to make it for dinner that night.  My only problem was that I would be getting home to late to really marinate the salmon for 30 min.  So as soon as I got home I mixed up the marinade an probably only let it sit for about 5 or 10 min.  Popped it in the oven for more like 30 min. instead of the 20 min. in the recipe.  I used real maple syrup and had no problem with the marinade burning up.  The salmon came out done perfectly and had a really great taste.  Next time I make this I will marinade it for the full amount of time just to see what the difference in taste would be.  If you don't have the full 30 min to marinade I wouldn't let it stop you from trying this recipe.

text:
My new favorite salmon recipe! I make it so much that measurements are not necessary anymore and I throw things in by taste. If you love garlic, adding more minced garlic is definitely the way to go. Don't forget or omit the garlic salt! Even though you've put in minced garlic, the garlic salt is still needed for that extra bit of parsley flavor. Wonderful  easy recipe and I'm so glad I found it and was able to make it right without burning my kitchen down!

text:
Used Bird Dog Maple Whiskey for the marinade instead of maple syrup which I didn't have. (Funny I would have maple whiskey but not maple syrup!) Baked butternut squash noodles tossed with olive oil and minced garlic on a baking sheet at 400 for 10 minutes first. Then added the marinated salmon on top and cooked another 20 minutes. I poured the marinade over the salmon and squash for cooking. Very good!

text:
Wow! This recipe is a keeper!! The only difference I made was that instead of baking it, I cooked the salmon in my Instant Pot at high pressure for 4 minutes (do 3 minutes for smaller portions), then did a quick release. While the salmon was cooking, I boiled down the marinade in a saucepan on the stove, which turned into a thick, decadent sauce as it cooled.... think of a topping on a Sundae!! Will be doing this one again....and again!!!

text:
Very easy dinner!  Used the foil method that other reviewers suggested to ensure the salmon fillet was completely submerged in the marinade/sauce. Started with 20 minutes, then kept checking every 5 minutes until it looked cooked through. Salmon didn't  get dry at all and cooked all the way through! Served with a side of green beans and garlic mashed potatoes. Delicious, will cook again maybe with a little less maple syrup and a bit of crushed red pepper :)

text:
This has become one of my favorite dishes to cook for dinner! I used the ingredients exactly as posted. I marinate the salmon for 30 minutes and bake it in a 10" round aluminum pan that is lined with aluminum foil on the bottom. 20 minutes at 350 degrees and it comes out perfect. The sauce does not dry out while baking on the foil, and the foil makes cleanup easy afterward!

text:
This was a hit, but we didn't finish the whole portion. I saved the fish and put it on salad of mixed greens (baby spring and arugula), red grapes (seedless & halved), and a nice balsamic dressing. I used what I had, but I think the key was a slightly sweet dressing, slightly tart lettuce, and the crunch and sweetness of the grapes. Also, I wrapped the salmon in the cooking foil that still had some marinade in it before I refrigerated it. Perfect lunch.

text:
This is a delicious dish! I usually use an olive oil-garlic marinade for baked salmon, but am now a convert to this sweet alternative. I followed the recipe almost entirely, although I replaced a quarter of the called-for amount of maple syrup with honey instead.Then I folded a piece of  aluminum foil around the salmon and placed it in a glass ovenproof dish for cooking.  I paired the fish with basmati rice, drizzled with Thai chili sauce (mixed with a bit of honey to lessen the heat) and topped with toasted sesame seeds. I sprinkled some of the seeds over the salmon, as well. Thanks, STARFLOWER, for this fantastic, easy-to-follow recipe!

Like Starflower, my husband didnât care much for salmon until he had this recipe.  He declared it a âKeeperâ after just a couple of bites!  I followed the suggestions to increase the minced garlic (I grated mine) and use sea salt instead of garlic salt and to bake it for about 4-6 minutes per 1/2" thickness and I'm so glad I did both.  Next time I'll cook it a couple less minutes, then broil it for the last two as was also suggested.  Also,  I only fixed  two 3/4" filets with the full recipe of marinade.  I would double the marinade if I were to fix four.  Excellent and easy recipe.  Thank you, Starflower!

Arby Humphrey

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5548884.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great marinade recipe, quick and easy!  For an Asian twist add just a little fresh grated, or dried ginger.  The salmon can be baked, cooked on the stovetop, or it's  delicious cooked on a smoky grill.  Be very carefull not to overcook the fish.  Salmon is easy to overcook, it dries out and loses flavor. To cook fish perfectly, remove it from the heat source before it appears fully cooked, while there is still some translucency in the middle. Take a sharp knife or fork and peek into the thickest part. If the fish flakes easily, but still has some translucency in the middle, it is done. It should not, however, look raw. Fish keeps cooking for several minutes after being removed from the heat. If you wait until the fish looks done, it will be dry by the time it reaches the table.
Review:

text:
I gave this recipe to my husband, as a parting gift when I took the kids and left him! ... Sad, but true... and the kids tell me that he serves this to them every time they visit him on alternate weekends. I did all the cooking for over 18 years, and I wanted to help him learn to cook some "real" food for himself and the kids. This recipe was simple, and with the help of my 11-year old daughter, it was an instant favorite for him. It's comforting to know that my kids are eating healthy meals at home with their dad, along with the boxed macaroni & cheese! This recipe will hopefully be the first of many that give my ex-husband confidence in the kitchen, so he can learn to cook for himself and the kids. He can rely less on take out and packaged foods, so he can save his money to pay child support. :^) THANKS for sharing this easy recipe with our family... it has made our transition just a little bit smoother for all.

Great recipe! The marinade was tasty. I added some fresh grated ginger for a bit of a zing.  I marinated for 1/2 hour and baked on foil at 425 for 16 minutes, until just flaking. The glaze carameled a bit and I sponned on the reserved liquid over the salmon twice while it baked. This was superb  as a warm salad on a bed of baby greens with some boiled baby potatoes, pearl onions and green beans. Canât wait to make it again!

userID:
22229503
Display Name:
Miranda Waterman
isPro:

0

favoritesCount:

0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5572735.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Perfect! I wound up marinading for only 10 minutes per side since it was late, but I seared the filet for 2 minutes on each side in a preheated cast iron to maintain flavor before putting it in the oven for at 400 degrees for 10 minutes. An extra person came over in the time I was cooking so to help spread out the fish, I shredded the filet with a fork and mixed it into the remaining marinade to use as onigiri rice ball stuffing. Incredible!! I highly recommend it. Season every 2 cups white rice once it's done cooking with 1/5c vinegar, 2tbsp sugar, and 1tsp salt mixed together and microwaved to dissolve. Pour over rice and mix thoroughly. 2 cups wasn't quite enough for the whole pound of fish, but I was feeding four people and 2 cups of rice usually goes a long way. Definitely making this recipe again, with easy at home ingredients all I have to do is go pick up fish on my way home.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2017-08-09T02:00:33.06
helpfulCount:

region:

country:
None
text:
I make this all the time. My hubby and I love this salmon recipe. My mom, dad, and brother also love this recipe when I made if for a family BBQ. I admit that I leave out the garlic salt and sub in sea salt and some garlic granules instead, so same difference I guess? My mom, who doesn't like seafood much said that this recipe made her want to have a second helping of salmon. Sometimes I do like to modify the original recipe a little and it always turns out great. I like to add a dash of liquid smoke, and some parsley to the marinade. Some days I halve the maple syrup and use a few scoops of brown sugar mixed with a few drops of maple flavoring so the salmon gets a nice crust on top.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is good, but I omitted the garlic and garlic salt.  I added the pure maple syrup, 2 T soy sauce and I subbed 1 t chili in adobe. Cooked in small saucepan for 3-4 minutes until thickened. Off heat added a couple Tbls lime or lemon juice.  Marinated for 20 min then added some black pepper and applied the thick sauce/marinade with a brush and cooked at 400 for  13 min.  Then brushed again when done - BEST ever!

text:
This is by far my favorite salmon recipe EVER. My boyfriend isn't a fan of that "fish" flavor and if you're looking for that, this is the recipe for you. The first time I made it, i made it twice in one week. My boyfriend told me "I love this recipe so much, don't make it often!" He thinks this recipe is such a treat and I couldn't agree more. I put these in foil packets and made sure I spooned on the extra marinade in the packets. When the fish was nearly done I opened the foils and put the oven on broil for that "crust" I like on fish. If I could give this more than 5 stars, I certainly would!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used a wild caught salmon filet with the skin still on it, so I did not turn the fish during cooking. I cooked it skin side up, so that the fish would cook in the marinade vs. the skin. I followed the recipe almost exactly, except I used garlic powder instead of garlic salt, no black pepper (I don't like it), and real Vermont maple syrup. I placed the fish on foil in the baking dish for easier clean-up. The fish cooked just fine, but it was way too sweet for me. served with parsley brown rice, and dill carrots.

None
text:
I made the recipe with a few minor adjustments. I substituted  low sodium tamari for the soy sauce , I eliminated the garlic salt and used one very large garlic clove.
Plus I cooked the salmon in an aluminum pouch and did not flip it; just cooked it for 20-25 minutes (25 mins for thick salmon filets).
Served the salmon with roasted garlic couscous & grilled yellow squash. Easy & delicious!

text:
My father has a secret recipe for an amazing baked salmon which all who tried love and I'm alway trying to compete with it. I think I finally found a match! This salmon is so yummy and super easy to make, perfect for beginners or those who are unsure of how to season fish. If you love the taste of salty/sweetness and salmon this is the way to make it! I used regular salt and garlic, not garlic salt, less sodium soy sauce, and pure organic grade A dark maple syrup. Will be making this again for sure!

(one absolutely hates fish)  I took other reviewers suggestions and baked it in foil, then opened for the last 5 min or so and put under the broiler. country:

text:
I followed the recipe as I usually do the first time, unless there is something objectionable, but that did not apply here.  The only thing I did differently was I let the Salmon marinate for an hour as my piece was pretty thick.  The flavor never did penetrate the fish, but turned out to be a very tasty glaze.  However, next time I will add a bit of ginger and a dash of cayenne (for my personal taste-the recipe is not lacking.)  The 20 min. cook-time was exactly right for my cut, as it came out tender, flaky,and just barely this side of pink.  It was so moist and delicious, with the addition of my 2 other fave ingreds., this could rival a $30. restaurant entree and one more star from me.  Next time, dear, next time.  Thanks so much for sharing; it was just what I was craving.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I enjoyed this quite a bit. I seasoned the salmon with kosher salt and black pepper before marinating it, and topped it with dried red pepper flakes before serving. I used fresh, skin-on Alaskan Salmon fillets (the skin ended up being soggy, but that was a technical purchasing mistake on my part, make sure to buy skinless fillets!). I served this with Jasmine Rice (with some leftover marinade spooned over it, topped with sesame seeds) and mixed frozen vegetables (with black pepper maple bacon bits mixed in) on the side. Overall, the salmon was really good! The balance between sweet and salty was perfect, I would recommend this dish!

userID:
8989361
Display Name:
Vic
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
26
favoritesCount:
109
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3980482.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this  recipe for a whole salmon for my brother's wedding.  This recipe is by far the simplest recipe I've ever followed. Due to its simplicity, I thought I'd add very subtle ingredients - namely the zest and juice of one lemon, plus  1tbsp grated ginger.  Excellent marinating tip to marinate in aluminum foil by the way! I baked the whole salmon (which was halved by the way) skin side up in the oven for half an hour. In the last 5 minutes, I tested the flake of the belly and saw that it could stand a few more minutes. So I shut off the oven and timed it for approximately 6 minutes. It came out perfect! I carefully drained the marinade to a sauce pan and boiled it and added gradually added cornstarch mixed with water to avoid clumps, to thicken the sauce. Upon serving, I flipped the fish onto its skin and garnished with chopped chives and drizzled the boiled marinade over the fish. It was exactly as I imagined it to be and it was delish! This is going to be a repeat dish in my home! Thank you Starflower!
Review:
Rating:
5

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was marvelous! I followed the directions and all the ingredients except that I did not have cardamon. But I looked up the substitution and followed what it said which was equal parts ground cinnamon powder and nutmeg. So the Cardamon ended up being 1/2 teaspoon nutmeg and 1/2 teaspoon ground cinnamon. I think next time I will go 1/4 teaspoon ground cinnamon because I thought the cinnamon was just a little overpowering. I also added some dried dill to the mixture. One other thing I did was that while the salmon was frying I went a head and added the rest of the liquid  mixture plus squeezed in a whole lemon. I just can't see eating any seafood without lemon. It was the best salmon I have ever cooked by far and I have tried very many different and various ways to cook salmon. I cooked a green beans recipe that also was amazing!  I believe it was called Ken-shoo green beans. I also cooked wild rice and in the rice I added dried dill  and zest a whole lemon Plus about a tablespoon of cilantro. The whole meal was D Lish!

city:

region:
