country:
None
text:
This was delish! For our family I will definitely be adding some spice next time. I took the advice of others and thickened the sauce with some cornstarch after it was cooked. For those who haven't used cornstarch as a thickener you mix a little room temp water with cornstarch and stir till combined (which takes a few secs only) and pour the mix into the sauce and simmer. I didn't use garlic salt just fresh garlic. I also peeled the skin after the salmon was cooked and crisped it up under the broiler and it made amazing salmon skin.

text:
This is possibly the easiest, really good recipe ever. I took the advice of other reviewers and added some freshly grated ginger, omitted the garlic salt, wrapped the salmon in aluminum foil, poured the marinade over it and left it in the fridge for 30 minutes. Then 20 minutes in a 400-degree oven, leaving it wrapped for the first ten minutes, then turning it over and leaving it unwrapped for the last ten. *So* good.

text:
This was very easy and very tasty!
As other reviewers did, I left out the garlic salt and added chopped fresh ginger. It was delicious!
I was also fixing asparagus for the meal so I decided to try some of this marinate/glaze on them too. I put the trimmed asparagus spears in a shallow baking dish and spooned some of the marinate over them and roasted at 400Â° for about 10 minutes with the salmon. It was wonderful and I will be using this recipe again for both salmon and asparagus.

text:
Only change I made was to use garlic powder in place of garlic salt.  I marinated the salmon skin-side up for 25 minutes, then turned on the oven.  It took about 10 minutes for the oven to preheat, so my salmon marinated for about 35 minutes.  It only took about 12 minutes for my filets to cook.  I served them and drizzled some of the marinade over them.  Everyone loved it!  Quick, easy, healthy and delicious.  Thanks for the recipe!

text:
One of my favorite salmon recipes!!! Very tasty and fast! However, I do cook it differently based on another recipe. I put two pieces of aluminum foil in a glass dish, place fillets in the aluminum foil, cover with marinade, and seal. I marinate for 20 minutes. Then, bake 35 to 45 minutes at 375 degrees (keeping fish in foil), until easily flaked with a fork.

text:
This recipe is amazing, tastes amazing and super simple and easy.  I use real maple syrup, cheapest is at Trader Joes.  And I put the salmon and mixture in a plastic sealed baggie for a while (an hour) in the fridge skin side up the whole time, making sure all the meat is laying in the marinade.  

Other than that, I follow the recipe to a "t" and it is really super yummy.  

Must add, I live in the Pacific Northwest so the quality of the salmon is probably higher than in other areas.  Making this tonight with freshly caught Chinook from the Cascade Locks.

userID:
3710970
Display Name:
dreissman@aol.com
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
5
favoritesCount:
12
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677179.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Thank you for this recipe.  The beauty of this dish is that it lets the salmon's taste shine and you can't really screw it up if you follow the directions.  You can't really taste that it has maple syrup but you know there is a sweetness with the soy.  It's easy.  Use a very large plastic ziplock bag, dump in the ingredients, shake it, place the salmon in one piece at a time and turn them, then put in the fridge for 30 minutes.  My very picky teenager ate it (he hates when I cook) and asked if he could eat the rest of it - five more pieces and they were large - the answer was no because we have other people to feed.  I did add ginger but just a few swipes.  Did not add garlic salt as I didn't have it.   I doubled the recipe and it was more than enough for 3 1/2 pounds as it covered all the pieces well.  I lined a 1 1/2 inch baking pan with aluminum foil and put it into the preheated oven uncovered for 20 minutes, turned off the oven and left it in for 10 more minutes and then took it out to come to room temperature.  As a side to go with it I did a stir fry of king oyster mushrooms, a bunch of other asian mushrooms and asparagus, garlic and ginger.  Really worked well together.   I used farm raised salmon which is much, much milder than wild.  I wouldn't use it with wild salmon (the red one) as the flavors might compete.

5

I was excited about trying this recipe because I love all the ingredients in it.  Unfortunately, I was disappointed with the taste.  I did not like the maple flavor with the salmon and soy sauce at all.  In addition, in my opinion it needed lemon to tone down the sweetness and saltiness.  Next time I will return to honey and dijon, or just to lemon and garlic.

This was delicious. Hubby loved it.  I did use fresh garlic, and I did increase recipe and reduce half of recipe on stove while fish was cooking. I got side-tracked sauteeing some veggies and the broiler did start to burn the sauce, but I got it out just in time.

text:
I love this salmon recipe. When I have guests over who I've cooked this for, they actually request it ahead of time. 
I use fresh Atlantic Salmon (never frozen), real maple syrup (from Costco), and Kikkoman soya sauce. Upon reading the negative reviews, I thought I would specify what ingredients might be making / breaking the dish for you. Everyone I have over loves it, and my picky toddler also scarfs it down. The sauce is amazing on rice too, mmm!

text:
Okay to be honest, I tweak this recipe occasionally by adding toasted sesame seeds, sometimes I add in some minced scallions for a little color.  Whenever possible I use Grade B maple syrup for the more intense flavor, but this marinade is by far my favorite and I use it on more than just salmon.  It's an easy go-to recipe and tonight I'll make the fish on my grill instead of in the oven.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I liked this a lot.  Yes, it was sweet.  But as the poster mentioned, maple syrup is soooo yummy.  Which brings me to my first point: use REAL maple syrup.  Not the flavored high fructose corn syrup (lite or otherwise!) - when a recipe calls for maple syrup, it means the concentrated tree sap; don't substitute, it never turns out right.  I added 1/2 t horseradish as someone mentioned; it took away some of the sweet without adding a strong flavor.  I also took that extra marinade and threw it on my stove to boil for a few minutes.  Made the yummiest glaze.  The kids loved this.  In fact, I had a hard time stopping them from eating the marinade (before I added the salmon)!

Will definitely make again and will use this marinade with other dishes as well!

None
text:
Great recipe and super easy. I've made this many times and it's foolproof. I always make 1 fillet just for me...I defrost frozen salmon from Costco. I use 1T soy sauce + 1T real maple syrup + black pepper + hot red pepper flakes and it's perfect. (I like spicy and have a garlic intolerance).  Wrapped in foil pouch and opened last 5 minutes as others suggested - perfectly cooked, loved the sauce over rice, and no clean up.  Delicious!  My only suggestion vs others who do last 5 minutes on broil - I don't broil with glass dishes. It's dangerous - they can explode as glass is not intended to go to 500 degrees. Safety first.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614242.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I went to the Highland County Maple Festival this year and brought home some maple syrup. I searched around allrecipes.com for some recipes to use my syrup in and this salmon dish caught my eye. It's now my favorite way to prepare salmon. I prepare the fish as directed, then serve it with rice, red leaf lettuce, and a pickled Asian vegetable. Set out a bottle of Sriracha hot sauce (that's the stuff you see in Chinese restaurants). From their plate, diners lift a leaf of lettuce, add some rice to the top of it, put a bit of the salmon on the rice and roll it up. Add the pickled veggie to the roll, or just have it on the side. Add the hot sauce to the roll if adventuresome. Oh my yum!

text:
Great recipe. It is basically teriyaki flavored when all is said and done. Dont use fake "maple" pancake syrup. Grade D real maple syrup works fine. 

I only marinated for like 5 minutes then used the excess sauce as a glaze. Didnt turn over. Baked for about 15 minutes then swapped to broiler like  someone else suggested for 3-5 minutes after spoonong over any sauce dripping. Came out awesomely.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674133.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I eat a lot of salmon and am always looking for a new recipe. This is a real winner! I made it only for myself, so adjusted the ingredients accordingly. I had wild sockeye salmon that I had bought  and froze. I thawed it and put it in a ziplock bag, skin up with the marinade. After reading the reviews I decided to add some fresh ginger since I had it on hand. Gave it a nice zing. I used real maple syrup, not pancake syrup. I used my Le Creuset fish skillet (which I was able to find brand new at a garage sale this summer for $4 and is the BEST pan I own.) When I preheated the oven, I put the skillet in and when the oven was ready I sprayed the skillet with cooking spray. When I lay the fish skin down it made the most wonderful sizzling sound. It was ready in 15 min.  In the meantime I reduced the marinade in a small pan on the stovetop and poured that over to serve it. Oh my, was that a treat! Thank you, Starflower!

text:
This recipe is ridiculous - it is so good it actually made my kids LOVE salmon which they used to seriously despise. A few days after I made this recipe, (they practically licked their plates clean), we were passing the fish case at the supermarket. The silver brite salmon filets caught my middle son's eye. He stopped in his tracks mesmerized and muttered "Salmon?" Followed by a more excited "Is that Salmon?!" Then my other two joined in. "Where? Salmon?" They were all drawn to the case. Pressing their faces and palms against the glass all three were chanting "Saaalmon. Saaaalmon." It was an embarrassing proud moment - until a lady next to us said, "wow, they really like Salmon, huh?" Then it was just embarrassing. I cheated - I really didn't marinate, more like poured it on 5 min before cooking and then threw it on the grill. Ridiculously easy, ridiculously awesome. How the heck did you come up with this? Impressive! (Oh, the grown ups loved it too!)

text:
I doubled the marinade so I would have some extra to make a sauce with. For some reason, the sauce was overly sweet. Not so the salmon, though - it was absolutely delicious, with a perfect balance of maple sweetness and savory soy sauce. 

I made three changes: I used garlic powder instead of garlic salt, because that's what I had (the soy sauce is plenty salty, anyway); I baked the salmon in a covered casserole; and my salmon filet needed to cook about 25 minutes rather than 20.

text:
GREAT baked salmon recipe.  
Minor changes made this dish exactly what we were looking for:
Agave Nectar instead of maple syrup
Garlic powder instead of garlic salt (soy sauce has enough saltiness & sodium)
We had to bake ours for 25 mins as our filets were a bit thicker & needed the extra time.

Will be making again!

text:
I made this last night and it was AMAZING!  Didn't change a thing, except I made a litte extra marinade.  When it was ready for the oven I did as another suggested and poured some of it off into a saucepan, added a little corn starch to thicken and drizzled this on when it came out.  Wow, was this a hit.  I usually plank salmon on the grill after a brief marinade and my husband doesn't like salmon.  Last night he was absolutely raving and says next time we have guests this is what he wants me to make!  Who would'a thunk-maple syrup, soy sauce, and garlic!  I'm going to adapt that for other things!

text:
I've made this twice and love it.  I grilled it for 1  minute flesh down to get some nice grill lines and then I turned it skin side down over indirect heat until it was done.  1 lb was closer to 3 servings with a side dish, not 4.  I've marinated it for just an hour and that worked, but I think 2 or more is better.

text:
I used this recipe for my family of four and everyone raved! I adapted this recipe a few days later to use with chicken, and again everyone raved! You can substitute Agave nectar for the maple syrup for a slightly different flavor profile, using the same measurements. I continue to tinker with it, changing a little here and a little there to suit whatever meat I'm using at the time. Try it out! I highly recommend this one!

text:
This recipe is amazingly good! My husband bought me a plank of salmon as a treat (he hates fish, so I don't get to eat it that often) and I had originally planned on grilling it. However, it was cold and rainy that day and so I went in search of another idea and found this. It was so simple! I used garlic power as I didn't have any cloves on hand. I also wrapped mine in foil as some other users had suggested, and it made for an overly simple clean-up. I didn't get the crispy top others did, but I'll play with it and try for next time. Since I was the only one eating, I had leftovers, and they seemed even better the next day. Thanks for sharing the recipe!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
this is a good recipe. I made this a few times. My wife loves it.  I also suggest marinating the Salmon fillets in milk for 10 min., take a cup of seasoned or unseasoned bread crumbs.  Add smokehouse maple seasoning to the bread crumbs, Season to taste. I use a table spoon to one cup of bread crumbs. Take one egg and beat the egg until frothy, Dip the salmon fillet in the egg and dredge it through the bread crumbs. Bake as the recipe calls for . While the salmon is baking, mix some mustard with the maple syrup. Add  1/4 cup  of syrup to two table spoons of mustard.   Also add 1/4 cup of melted butter.
Or mix to taste. Home made honey mustard works well too. When salmon is done drizzle the mustard sauce over the fillets.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have never made salmon before now.  I only ordered it in restaurants because I was afraid to make it at home and always thought salmon tasted fishy compared to other fish.  Now I know it just needs to be super fresh and that you need to remove the gray matter on the bottom after cooking.  That is what tastes fishy as it is part of the skin.  This was easy, elegant and excellent tasting.  I followed other suggestions and marinated and baked in a foil pouch then opened it at the top for the last 5 minutes under the broiler.  I didn't make any changes but I did use pure maple syrup from Vermont which is thicker and richer and I think it gave it a thicker sauce and broiled nicely with a crispy top. Thank you for the great recipe.

text:
Loved this - so simple to make and delicious!! 
 I didn't use garlic, just the garlic salt and pepper.  I cut back a little on the soy sauce for my sweet tooth.  
I used high quality salmon from a good local meat shop, used real maple syrup which made a difference, but the store brand soy sauce which didn't seem to make a difference.  I also remembered, after baking it about 20 min. like the recipe said, that the best way to cook fish is in the microwave.  So I popped it in the microwave for a couple minutes and it came out perfect!

This was so tasty! I spruced it up by taking the other reviewer's advice and didn't use the garlic powder. I then used the cayenne pepper. Just a sprinkle. I put the fish in foil packets with carrots and celery. I marinated the fish for 30 minutes in the refrigerator, flipping at the 15 minute mark. I ended up baking the fish the for 18 minutes.   The result is a spicy and tangy and sweet! Delicious! Definitely make again.

A nice, mildly sweet, salmon recipe.  We grilled it instead of baking it and it was wonderful. text:
Very easy & yummy!  I'm usually not a huge salmon fan, but I really enjoyed this recipe.  The marinade only takes a few minutes to mix up.  I did put fish in a tin foil sack I made with 2 pieces of foil and then drizzled the marinade over it.  Bake for 15-17 minutes, then broil for 5-6 minutes.  A+ in my book!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I really like salmon and this is a nice way to prepare it.  The flavor is sweet and tangy without overpowering the natural flavor of the fish.  Make sure you use REAL maple syrup to get the most out of this recipe.  Also don't overcook the fish!  It should flake easily while still retaining a little color inside.  It's easy to do (trust me, I know) so keep an eye on it.  Baking per the recipe is great or you could grill the fish if so inclined.  Once again, make sure not to grill it to death!  It's a good recipe that's definitely worth a try!

text:
Amazing flavor for such a simple recipe! I marinated a pound of salmon in plastic baggie - doubled the recipe because I like a lot of sauce. Instead of discarding the marinade, I poured it over the salmon and baked it for about twenty minutes, until the sauce thickened. It was delicious! text:
I haven't traditionally been a "fish" person. In fact, it's only been in the last 7 years that I've eaten it. This is a good recipe. 20 minutes in the oven was too short for my cut of fish. I liked the idea of incorporating brown sugar into the mix, wrapping in foil for marinade step, and having the fish spend a few minutes in the broiler. It was a great meal. I served with some Jasmine rice that I made in my rice cooker. Could not be an easier meal!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/47061.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this recipe five times. It is my absolute favorite way to eat salmon! I actually taught my non-cooking mother to make this, which she then in turn cooked for friends, who were very impressed by her sudden skill. ;-) If you never cook fish, I believe this is a great recipe to start with!  A few notes on the marinade: I've found that I always need to make more because I add it to the foil wraps. It's also important to use real maple syrup, as fake syrup has a different kind of sweet taste that I didn't like as much. I add a lot more garlic, too, because we love garlic.  Make a foil "pouch" to bake the fish in! This way, it can cook in the marinade, too, and it prevents a mess in your pan. :-) The fish cooked perfectly when I did this.
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
I have to say that I don't like salmon all that much, and for some reason, I figured that Aunt Jemima would be equivalent to maple syrup...that having been said, this is definitely one of the worst 4+ star recipes I've made.  I kept finding myself trying to add more saltiness and sour flavorings...as if I could somehow rescue our expensive cut of salmon and return it to the lemon pepper we -should- have bathed it in.  Again, I'm not one to slam someone else's creation.  Maybe there was something wrong with the salmon.  And again, I'm not a big fan of it in the first place...  I'm giving it two stars, because it probably would've been better if I'd used real maple syrup.

The recipe is easy and quick. I used Garlic Powder instead of Garlic Salt. It was good and my husband loved it. I, on the other hand didn't particularly care for the salmon taste with sweetness. Display Name:
Michelle Roth-Kiva
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2689406.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
UPDATE: I GUESS MY TASTEBUDS ARE CHANGING WITH AGE BECAUSE AFTR JUST ONE BITE, I FELL IN LOVE WITH THIS. MY MOM REQUESTED I MADE SALMON FOR HER BDAY, SO I GAVE THIS A SECOND GO-AROUND. I CHANGED NOTHING AND AND SOOOO GLAD I DIDN'T. THIS WAS ABSOLUTELY PERFECT! Meh. I was hoping to recreate a similar dish I had on the Disney Wonder last year. Animator's Palate served an AWESOME maple glazed salmon over mashed red potatoes with a side of steamed green beans that was TO DIE FOR!!! While tasty, this just wasn't what I was looking for. :( The sauce is only mildly sweet and the garlic flavor is a bit overpowering (and I LOVE the stuff - 40 clove garlic chicken please!!!). Since my fiance picked up 1 lb. worth of salmon steaks, I used those instead, but would have prefered filets. I pretty much followed STARFLOWER's directions exactly except for wrapping each steak (there were two) in a double thickness of aluminum foil and drizzling with just a little of the maple syrup/glaze. I baked covered, for 20 minutes and then broiled, slightly opened for another 3. I made a sauce with the remaining glaze by heating it over med-high heat and adding 1 T cornstarch mixed with 2 T cold water to thicken. Served with refrigerated mashed red potatoes and honey carrots I picked up in my grocer's frozen foods section (I wanted dinner to be quick tonight), this was an "OK" meal. Thanks for sharing your idea, STARFLOWER :)

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/358767.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is an easy marinade to make a flavorful meal. I love how it is ingredients I already have. I marinade mine in a ziploc for 30 mins prior to baking. I drizzle half the marinade on the salmon while baking, then add the last half of it the last 5 mins or so. This causes it to thicken up. I then spoon the sauce over each piece of salmon. I usually make more marinade then it calls for so I can have extra. EDIT: I also like to add a 1/2 tsp of cayanne pepper to give this a kick. Yummy!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Yum! Do not change recipe at all for time!  Marinate only 30 minutes.

I had cut to 15 minutes marinating time after reading the reviews and watching the salmon soaking up the syrup mixture.   Was not too sweet at all and founds ourselves scraping the juices from the pan to add more of the yummy flavor.  Next time, will marinate 30 minutes.   
This was the first time 7yr dd said she liked salmon and the fish sticks were pushed to the side.   
If you like easy recipes that taste like you spent a lot of time on it, this is a great one.
We had fried cabbage/onion with it, and for some reason tasted really good together.  I guess the sweet and salty flavors.
Will fancy up the side dishes next time we have company with asparagus and roasted potatoes.  All ready to eat this again.

text:
Omitted the garlic salt (too much salt in the soy sauce anyway), used about a tsp of minced garlic and used medium amber maple syrup to be exact and wow is this good. I love how everything beautifully plays off of each other. The soy sauce, the garlic, the maple. You can taste it all. I'm not usually one for sweet dishes but I love this. It's not super sweet but a bit mildly sweet instead. So unless someone just hates anything sweet they'd probably like this. Definitely something I will be making again and again.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very tasty recipe, and easy to make!  I had approximately 2 pounds of salmon fillets, so I increased the ingredients accordingly.  The only minor adjustment I made was that I marinated the fish in the fridge for around 45 minutes while I made a side dish (garlic red potatoes), and I baked it for around 25 to 30 minutes (since I was using double the amount of fish).  And you know what, I didn't have any genuine maple syrup--I previously checked it out at the grocery store, and the price is a bit too spendy for my budget--so I used regular pancake syrup instead.  It turned out great!  It added just the right touch of sweetness to balance out the saltiness of the soy sauce and other seasonings.

text:
My entire family loved this recipe. The fish was very fresh, and extremely moist. We grilled it, rather than baked. I used exactly 1/4 cup of maple syrup, and thought it could use a bit more. I skipped the garlic salt, and doubled the minced garlic. I also added a dash of ground ginger. I was worried that 2.25 pounds of salmon fillet would be too much for the four of us--but, there wasn't a crumb left!

text:
Another 5 star from my picky hubby! I made a few changes and it was 10 stars in my book. No garlic salt, only fresh garlic. I replaced the garlic salt with seasoned salt, added a pinch of ginger, placed all in foil and put in fridge for 30 minutes. Then I sauteed in a skillet with 1 t butter and all of the marinade, top salmon with a piece of buttered parchment paper (sounds crazy but keeps the moisture in, yummy) and cook 4 min each side. Served with rice (topped the salmon and rice with sauce from skillet) and some southern greens....restaurant quality

text:
Quick and easy, with a yummy teriyaki-type flavor!  I add ginger to the marinade mix, and blend all ingredients together before applying.  I salt & pepper the salmon and let it rech room temperature with the marinade over it.  I usually save some of the marinade mix to baste the salmon with as it cooks.  This also allows me to pay ver close attention as the salmon cooks, as I can't stand overcooked fish.

text:
This was good!  I tried it twice, once marinating for two hours then again marinating it overnight.  My only issue is that when I marinated it overnight, the marinade only penetrated the top layer of the fish so the flavor didn't go all the way through (which I would have liked).  That is probably more to do with how I marinated than anything though (I've never marinated fish before).  Also the maple flavor wasn't as strong as I would have liked, but I also used grade a medium instead of dark, so that might have had something to do with it.  I'll definitely try this again and keep tweaking until I find the right way to do it for me.  Overall a great recipe though, I definitely wouldn't have thought to prepare it this way!  Thanks!

My boyfriend loves salmon and gets it almost all the time when we go out to eat and he actually said that this tasted better than what he gets at a nice restaurant.  The only downfall to this recipe was the sauce gets stuck to the baking pan and you have to soak the pan right away and still scrub pretty hard to get it clean.  But the salmon tasted so good that the extra effort in cleaning is worth it.  :-)

Heres a tried and true !I made this with fresh caught coho salmon /full fillet wrapped in heavey foil twice .Then turned it a few over an outdoor woodburning fire pit at the campsite!I doubled the marinate because the fish was a good 8 pounder!After cleaning and gutting the coho salmon, I just poured the marinate inside and sealed with foil !All the other fisher/ campers agreed it was the best! Very few times can you find one that will work for fish over an open wood camp fire !PHENOMINAL and no mess to clean never used a pan or roaster!Made twice since excellent !!!!
